conclusion: Understanding the problem involves predicting which container liquid will flow into after passing through baffles.
The setup includes points labeled A, B, C, D and containers E, F, G with baffles in between.
There are pipes or something directing liquid from A, B, C, D towards containers at the bottom.
There are horizontal and diagonal lines representing baffles or obstacles.
Arrows point from A, B, C, D down towards containers with colored sections indicating starting points or container colors.
Colorful paths show possible flow of liquid from top to bottom with interactions with baffles.
Complex paths with multiple colors overlapping suggest mixing or merging of liquid streams.
Key is to trace the path of each liquid stream from A, B, C, D through baffles to see where they end up.
Liquid from A flows down and to the left, encountering a baffle directing it towards container E.
Liquid from B flows straight down, passing through horizontal baffles, aligning with container F.
Liquid from C flows down and to the right, encountering a diagonal baffle directing it towards container G.
Liquid from D flows straight down, similar to B but on the right side, aligning with container G.
